channel.title: A nice DIY project?
channel.description:
I'm looking for a nice DIY project that wont break the bank, and that I wont get bored of as soon as I finish. Thinking about [url=http://www.ladyada.net/make/fuzebox/index.html]Fuzebox[/url], but it doesn't seem all that great. Any other suggestions?
The Fuzebox is a fully open-source, DIY 8-bit game console. It is designed specifically for people who know a little bit of programming to expand into designing and creating their own video games and demos. A full-featured core runs in the background and does all the video and audio processing so that your code stays clean and easy to understand. [ul][li]Full 256 simultaneous output colors, 240x224 pixel resolution[/li] [li]Tile & sprite support[/li] [li]Two player ports, either with Super Nintendo or classic Nintendo controllers[/li] [li]NTSC RCA composite and S-video out (PAL not supported at this time)[/li] [li]4 channel output mono audio for music and effects[/li] [li]SD/MMC card support for future expansion[/li] [li]Built on an Atmel AVR core, 64KB flash and 4KB of RAM[/li] [li]Main microcontroller chip is preprogrammed with an STK500-compatible (sometimes referred to as Arduino-compatible) bootloader[/li] [li]Write game code in C, using fully open source tools on any platform[/li][/ul]
Anyone heard of them? It's based off of [url=http://uzebox.org/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page]Uzebox[/url], but from what I understand Uzebox comes assembled, and Fuzebox comes as a kit.

item.title: A nice DIY project?
item.dc:creator: @benny679 benny679
item.description:
@benny679 wrote:

A 4-bit computer running off solar power.

A computer in a 1’ by 6" box. I finished mine, 2gb ram, Pentium 4, slax Linux.

Or even FPGA

YOU FUCKER STOP IGNORING ME
[/quote][/quote]

item.title: A nice DIY project?
item.dc:creator: @shrogg shrogg
item.description:
@shrogg wrote:

@slightly offtopic

My project atm is making a portible Xbox original xD
so far i am getting it to run a 14" lcd monotor and the xbox off batterys, but its being a bit of a problem xD
once i get that done im going to start building a case, but yeah

@topic
i like the idea of gettin this kitset thing and making your own game console/games, and what about an arduino? i have one and its quite fun to play around with, as its not limited to the code on it, but also the circut that you build for it

http://www.arduino.cc/

Read full topic

item.title: A nice DIY project?
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:10, topic:348537”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=444916.msg3267983#msg3267983 date=1278992052]

make a portable n64

I would try, but I don’t have own any old consoles anymore. All i have is 2 360s and 2 Wiis. I don’t know where else to find them except ebay, and there is the issue if they actually work or not

You could put a modchip in the wii, although there really isn’t much of a need anymore due to software hacks.
[/quote]

I would, but I don’t really use them that much. Plus, I don’t even see a point for the mod chip, or even a software mod; Wii is fun enough as it is[/quote]

Free games played via portable hard drive is win, not to mention the other things like playing DVDs and such

Read full topic

You could put a modchip in the wii, although there really isn’t much of a need anymore due to software hacks.
[/quote]

I would, but I don’t really use them that much. Plus, I don’t even see a point for the mod chip, or even a software mod; Wii is fun enough as it is[/quote]

A software mod is definitely worth it, you get to play games from backups, and it opens up a bunch of other 3rd party games and applications that are all free.

item.title: A nice DIY project?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

I’m looking for a nice DIY project that wont break the bank, and that I wont get bored of as soon as I finish. Thinking about Fuzebox, but it doesn’t seem all that great. Any other suggestions?

The Fuzebox is a fully open-source, DIY 8-bit game console. It is designed specifically for people who know a little bit of programming to expand into designing and creating their own video games and demos. A full-featured core runs in the background and does all the video and audio processing so that your code stays clean and easy to understand.

[ul][li]Full 256 simultaneous output colors, 240x224 pixel resolution[/li]
[li]Tile & sprite support[/li]
[li]Two player ports, either with Super Nintendo or classic Nintendo controllers[/li]
[li]NTSC RCA composite and S-video out (PAL not supported at this time)[/li]
[li]4 channel output mono audio for music and effects[/li]
[li]SD/MMC card support for future expansion[/li]
[li]Built on an Atmel AVR core, 64KB flash and 4KB of RAM[/li]
[li]Main microcontroller chip is preprogrammed with an STK500-compatible (sometimes referred to as Arduino-compatible) bootloader[/li]
[li]Write game code in C, using fully open source tools on any platform[/li][/ul]

Anyone heard of them? It’s based off of Uzebox, but from what I understand Uzebox comes assembled, and Fuzebox comes as a kit.

Read full topic
